rounds.response:
K-4 offsuit is a mediocre holding in a heads-up situation. I'm out of position (I’m the big blind), the pot is 30 chips and Villain has already put in 20. With 990 effective stack I have plenty behind, so I’ll call the single raise and look to improve on the flop.  
[Call]

This is offsuit and not connected, so it’s a weak hand.

[Call]

I’m on the Button (actually SB because of the alternating-po­s­itions heads-up structure), so I act first on every post-flop street.  
Right now the pot is 80 and the betting is closed (0 to call).  
My hand K♦ 7♠ has a good king, but the four-flush board has heightened showdown value (it beats all pocket pairs below sevens and some ace-highs that don’t have the diamond) while also letting possible missed hands fold.  
I’ll take a small stab at the pot to try to collect it uncontested; if I get raised I can comfortably release.

[Bet 20]

Q♣ is borderline for heads-up, but it’s suited and deep-stacked enough. Folding would concede the blinds and put me down to 910; at 6.8 big-blinds behind, that’s dangerous. Instead I’ll defend and see the flop for the extra 10 chips.

[Call]

rounds.response:
Given the current state:
- Pot: 40  
- No bet to call on the flop (bet = 0)  
- Board: 4♣ A♠ 5♥ rainbow/ace-high – not especially coordinated.  
- Effective stack ~930 vs 1030 chips.

We hold Q♣ 7♣ – gutshot to a 6; our queen is overcard to all but the ace. It’s a soft board for one-pair hands at most, so we have some fold-equity on my queen high backdoor straight.

I elect to take the pot now while our range looks strong (our limp followed by check can then open the betting for value or semi-bluff on these textures).

[Check]
